awd_titl_txt: RUI:  Beta-amylases and transitory starch metabolism in Arabidopsis leaves
awd_abstract_narration:
Starch is an important energy-storage compound for plants and it makes up a significant portion of the human diet.  In leaves, starch accumulates in chloroplasts during the day, and is broken down at night to provide energy for the plant when photosynthesis is not possible.  The enzyme responsible for breaking down most of the starch at night is β-amylase (BAM).  There are nine BAM or BAM-like genes in the Arabidopsis genome, six of which (BAM 1, -2, -3, -4, -6 and -9) encode proteins that are targeted to chloroplasts.  Of these, only BAM1, -2, -3, and -6 are catalytically active.  The focus of this work is on BAM9, which is located in chloroplasts but is catalytically inactive.  Preliminary evidence from a mutant lacking BAM9, and from its structure and pattern of expression, suggests that it might play a role in regulating starch metabolism.  

The three objectives of this work are to 1) investigate the influence of BAM9 on the diurnal activity of the four active plastidic BAMs in leaf extracts of mutants lacking the proteins, 2) characterize the ability of pure BAM9 to bind starch and various small carbohydrates, and 3) identify and characterize protein(s) that bind to BAM9.  It is hypothesized that BAM9 acts to inhibit the activity of one or more of the active BAMs at dawn when starch degradation normally stops.  

This research will help to characterize the physiological functions of five plastid-targeted β-amylases in Arabidopsis, and will shed light on how starch metabolism is regulated in leaves, especially at the night/day transition.  The project will also train a number of undergraduates planning to pursue careers in science, and a teaching/research postdoctoral scholar planning to pursue a career at a predominantly undergraduate institution.

por.por_cntn:
Plants accumulate starch in leaves during the day and break it down at night to supply the plant with sugar when photosynthesis is not active. One of the primary enzymes that breaks down starch is β-amylase (BAM). The Arabidopsis thaliana genome contains nine BAM genes, six of which are located in the plastids where starch is found. Four other BAMs are thought to be catalytically inactive. We sought to investigate the functions of some of these plastid BAM proteins using plants lacking one or more of the BAM enzymes, and by using purified BAM proteins after expressing them in bacteria. We learned that in 5-week old plants the BAM activity is largely encoded by only BAM1 and BAM3. We then made a rather novel observation that the thermal properties of these two enzymes were different, with the day-active BAM1 having a higher thermal tolerance than the night-active BAM3. Cold stress is known to cause elevated levels of BAM3 mRNA, as others have observed, but we also found that the activity of the BAM3 protein was much lower after cold stress suggesting that it might be post-translationally inhibited. We discovered that purified BAM3 was modified at cysteine 433 by a compound that is known to accumulate after cold stress, and that this modification strongly inhibits the enzyme’s activity. This modification might explain how plants accumulate starch under cold stress. In contrast, BAM1 was unaffected by cold stress in plants and the pure BAM1 protein was not modified by the same compound. 

Previous reports indicated that of the active BAMs, only mutants lacking BAM3 accumulate starch in leaves, but we found that older plants lacking BAM2 and -6 also accumulated starch suggesting that these two enzymes are functional. By analyzing the sequence and structures of the BAM gene and protein we also learned that BAM2 is an ancient enzyme found in all plants. We then discovered the proper conditions with which to assay its activity and learned that it is highly unusual in being a tetramer and displaying cooperative kinetics involving a secondary binding site. Further characterization of this enzyme will likely lead to a new understanding of starch degradation in plants. We also attempted to determine the function of the catalytically inactive BAM9. We learned that it does not bind starch, and we have preliminary evidence of a binding partner in chloroplasts that could shed new light on the regulation of starch metabolism.

The broader impacts of this project involved training undergraduates in research, and preparing a postdoc for a position at a primarily undergraduate institution. Overall 15 undergraduates and two high school students participated in the research, 10 of which are coauthors on three papers that are either published, submitted or in prep.  Most of the students that have graduated have gone on to graduate or medical school. The postdoc co-mentored all of the undergraduates, taught two different courses and was ultimately successful in obtaining a tenure track position at a primarily undergraduate institution.
